title: Hethpool Linn Walking Route

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Information signs at the car park near Hethpool.
images.caption: Information signs at the car park near Hethpool. On a glorious late-summer day.

images.title: Cottages at Hethpool by David Purchase, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cottages at Hethpool

images.title: Callum Black / Footpath by the College Burn
images.caption: Footpath by the College Burn

images.title: Andrew Curtis / College Valley
images.caption: College Valley. On the right is The Bell. The north-west slope of Newton Tors is on the left. In the far distance, deep snow covers the high hills of the Border Ridge above the dark, forested, Sinkside Hill. Hethpool is round the corner.

images.title: Andrew Curtis / Footbridge over the College Burn, east of Hethpool Linn
images.caption: Footbridge over the College Burn, east of Hethpool Linn. Wild Goats are often seen in the College Valley. The Northumberland telling of the children's story, 'Three Billy Goats Gruff', is based on this bridge.

images.title: Andrew Curtis / Track west of West Hill
images.caption: Track west of West Hill. The snow-covered hill ahead is Wester Tor. The valley of the College Burn is down to the right.

images.title: Andrew Curtis / Small cairn on West Hill
images.caption: Small cairn on West Hill Staw. Farm is visible to the right, down in the valley. The range of hills behind includes Longknowe Hill and Kilham Hill

description: This walk in Northumberland visits the Hethpool Linn waterfall before a climb to the hillfort at West Hill. The falls are located in the College Valley, a beautiful and peaceful area with lots of interesting flora and fauna. The walk starts at the car park at Hethpool and heads along the College Burn to the waterfall. The route then heads north east to West Hill which includes an old hill fort on its 215 metre high summit. There's lovely views of the countryside and hills of the College Valley from here. After rounding the hill you can pick up a section of the St Cuthbert's Way and follow it west to Hethpool Mill before returning to the car park. You could extend the walk by continuing east to climb to Yeavering Bell. The noteworthy site includes the largest Iron Age hillfort in the region.
